description: From Middle English provisioun, from Old French provisïon, from Latin prōvīsiō (“preparation, foresight”), from prōvidēre (“provide”).

entries.meaning: An item of goods or supplies, especially food, obtained for future use.
The act of providing, or making previous preparation.
Money set aside for a future event.
(accounting) A liability or contra account to recognise likely future adverse events associated with current transactions.
examples: We increased our provision for bad debts on credit sales going into the recession.

entries.meaning: (law) A clause in a legal instrument, a law, etc., providing for a particular matter; stipulation; proviso.
examples: An arrest shall be made in accordance with the provisions of this Act.

entries.meaning: (Roman Catholicism) Regular induction into a benefice, comprehending nomination, collation, and installation.
(Britain, historical) A nomination by the pope to a benefice before it became vacant, depriving the patron of his right of presentation.

verbs.description: provision (third-person singular simple present provisions, present participle provisioning, simple past and past participle provisioned)

entries.meaning: (transitive, computing) To supply (a user) with an account, resources, etc. so that they can use a system.
